meanings.definition: To free someone from a misconception or error.
meanings.sent1: I had to disabuse my friend of the idea that cats are afraid of water.
meanings.sent2: She tried to disabuse him of the notion that all snakes are poisonous.
meanings.sent3: After many failed attempts, she finally managed to disabuse him of his fear of spiders.
meanings.sent4: The teacher's explanation helped to disabuse the students of their confusion about the topic.
meanings.sent5: He needed to disabuse himself of the belief that he was a terrible singer.

meanings.definition: To persuade someone to give up a false belief.
meanings.sent1: The evidence presented was enough to disabuse him of his superstitions.
meanings.sent2: She hoped to disabuse her brother of the idea that eating carrots improves eyesight.
meanings.sent3: His friends decided to play a prank to disabuse him of his belief in ghosts.
meanings.sent4: The experience served to disabuse her of the notion that all politicians are corrupt.
meanings.sent5: The book's conclusion aimed to disabuse readers of the myth that success comes overnight.
